awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Noble Gas Multi-Collector Mass Spectrometer for Geochronology and Geochemistry Research
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will establish a laboratory with state-of-the-art instruments for measuring noble gases in rock, mineral, and water samples, for geochronologic and geochemical studies in Earth, planetary, and environmental science. The facility will enable a wide variety of scientific studies by researchers and students at the University of Arizona and collaborating institutions. Some of the primary goals of these studies will be: 1) to investigate the timing and rates of geologic events and processes using radioisotopic dating, including faulting, magmatism, and erosion, 2) to characterize the behavior of noble gases in minerals to understand the material properties of natural crystals, and 3) to trace the movement and evolution of groundwater and other fluids in the Earth's subsurface. This project will also enable hands-on research training for students who will use the instruments and laboratory, helping them develop the quantitative and technical skills and experience for Earth, planetary, and environmental science.

The centerpiece of the laboratory will be a new multi-collector gas-source sector mass spectrometer and sample introduction equipment including devices for extracting gases using resistance (furnace) and laser heating, crushing of fluid-inclusions, and exsolution from fluids. State of the art high-resolution, high-sensitivity, and multi-collection capabilities of the mass spectrometer will enable simultaneous measurement of all isotopes of argon and neon, and helium will be measured by peak-hopping. Important research foci for the instrument will include 1) geo- and thermochronology using the 40Ar/39Ar system for applications in tectonic, detrital, volcanic, and fault-systems; 2) low-temperature 4He/3He thermochronology and understanding helium mobility in minerals; 3) cosmogenic and nucleogenic 21Ne dating for geomorphic applications and for dating secondary minerals like iron oxides; and 4) isotopic compositions and concentrations of noble gases for tracing the fluxes and evolution of subsurface fluid-rock systems. In addition to serving researchers and students at the University of Arizona, Utah State University, and University of Texas El Paso, the facility will also provide analytical services and research experience opportunities for collaborators at a variety of institutions, including universities and liberal arts colleges, through analyses and workshops for diverse cohorts of students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on the acquisition, construction, and routine operation of a new noble gas facility, the Arizona Noble Gas Laboratory, within the Department of Geosciences at the University of Arizona. The award provided funding to acquire two new multi-collector noble gas mass spectrometers (Argus VI and Helix MC+ made by Thermo Scientific), which were installed in the summer of 2019. With this newly constructed facility we are pursuing geochronologic and geochemical studies in Earth, planetary, and environmental sciences for researchers and students at the University of Arizona, collaborating institutions, and the broader NSF/EAR-supported community. Research has focused on geo/thermochronology utilizing the 40Ar/39Ar, K-Ar, 4He/3He, and 21Ne systems.

Specific goals of the project are to: 1) investigate the timing and rates of geologic events and processes using radioisotopic dating, including faulting, magmatism, and erosion; 2) characterize the behavior of noble gases in minerals to understand the material properties of natural crystals; and 3) trace the movement and evolution of groundwater and other fluids in the Earth's subsurface.

The Argus VI has been running nearly continuously during 2021 and 2022 for Ar dating. We have analyzed ~1000 flux monitors (Fish Canyon, Alder Creek, and Bodie Hills sandines), ~2000 standard air measurements, ~4000 analytical blanks, and over 200 unknowns via total fusion and incremental heating experiments. Projects have focused on slowly cooled muscovite and biotite from Tibet and Arizona; volcanic groundmass and plagioclase from the Cascade Mountains; sanidine from Africa; Mn-oxides from Utah; illite and smectite from Arizona, Colorado, Utah, and Wyoming; bentonite clay from turkey; and alunite, adularia, and sericite from economic deposits in Canada and South America.

Researchers involved in these projects have included:

-- 20 faculty members from the University of Arizona, University of Oregon, University of Wyoming, Karadeniz Technical University (Turkey), Macalester College, Purdue University, Princeton University, and Austin Peay State University.

-- 5 research scientists from the University of Arizona, Arizona Geological Survey, US Geological Survey, and Geological Survey of Japan.

-- 6 post-doctoral scholars from the University of Arizona, University of Wyoming, Caltech, and University of Washington. 

-- 11 graduate students from the University of Arizona and University of Wyoming.

-- 4 undergraduate students from the University of Arizona.

Four members of our research group have conducted outreach activities involving members of underrepresented communities in the Tucson area.

Results from this project have been reported in eight presentations at regional to international conferences, and provide the basis for nine papers that are in preparation for publication in peer-reviewed journals. Results have also been shared with members of the broader Earth Science community during Short Courses offered as part of the 2021 and 2022 National Meetings of the Geological Society of America. The courses included 17 (2021) and 21 (2022) participants ranging from undergraduate students to faculty members who oversee geo/thermochronology labs at other universities.

We also are working closely with researchers from other institutions to prepare proposals for future collaborative projects. These presently include: 1) The erosional response to mountain building in the Bergell Pluton and surrounding basins (NSF Tectonics); 2) Pliocene paleoclimate in the North American monsoon belt and implications for future climate change in the region (NSF FRES); 3) the tectonic history of the transition zone in western Arizona: A Record of Laramide Crustal Underthrusting/Bulldozing? (NSF Tectonics); 4) petrochronology and crystal-melt dynamics of a Miocene pluton in Japan (NSF Petrology and Geochemistry); 5) Timing of seamount and spreading center magmatism from Guadalupe Island, Mexico; and 6) Evolution of Subsurface Microbe-Rock-Fluid Systems (NSF FRES).
